The audience was already ecstatic when JME came out to perform alongside his brother, contributing to the already soaring energy with a thrilling display. Witnessing these giants perform together was nothing short of extraordinary, a true moment of cultural fusion. Contributing an international dimension, Vic Mensa, a frequent collaborator with Kanye, also showed up unexpectedly, demonstrating his unique vocal style. Both veteran supporters and new attendees cherished every moment of this landmark, unconventional concert. It was a chaotic yet brilliant evening that solidified Kanye’s fame for innovation and providing memorable events, leaving a lasting impression on London’s music landscape and on the enthusiastic fans who braved the weather for such a distinctive show.

It was a momentous occasion as the Commonwealth gold medallist, Josh Taylor, competed before his local supporters for the first time at a packed Meadowbank. "I hadn't anticipated such a swift conclusion," Taylor remarked to BBC Scotland after the bout. His manager, Barry McGuigan, lauded him, stating, "This young man is exceptionally gifted. We must ensure he takes on the appropriate challenges at the right junctures in his career."

His Hungarian opponent, Mate, entered the ring boasting an impressive track record of 17 victories from 22 contests. However, from the opening bell, it became clear that Mate was in for an arduous night. Taylor, renowned for his explosive power and strategic boxing, wasted no time in asserting his command. He moved with fluid precision, expertly cutting off the ring and delivering sharp, precise jabs that quickly flushed Mate’s face. The Edinburgh faithful, already charged with anticipation, erupted with cheers with every successful strike. Taylor’s southpaw stance, coupled with his formidable left hand, proved particularly challenging for Mate, who struggled to establish any rhythm or land any notable counters.

Less than a minute into the fight, a rapid-fire combination from Taylor—a left hook immediately followed by a straight right—sent Mate reeling back into the ropes. The Commonwealth champion, sensing an imminent finish, intensified his assault with relentless aggression. Mate displayed admirable fortitude, attempting to clinch and absorb the barrage, but Taylor's accuracy and volume of punches were simply overwhelming. Just past the midpoint of the initial round, a perfectly timed left uppercut from Taylor snapped Mate’s head back, followed by a devastating right hook that floored the visiting fighter.

The referee promptly initiated the count as Mate valiantly attempted to regain his footing, his gaze unfocused. Although he managed to rise at the count of nine, his legs were visibly unstable, prompting the referee to judiciously halt the match, deeming him unfit to continue. The official time of the stoppage was a mere 2 minutes and 10 seconds into the first round, a truly dominant and destructive display from the Prestonpans native. The capacity crowd at Meadowbank Arena erupted in a thunderous roar, rising in a standing ovation for their local hero.

Post-fight, a beaming Taylor relished the fervent adoration of the crowd, acknowledging their unwavering backing. Later, in an interview with BBC Scotland, he reflected on the win, reiterating his surprise at how quickly it unfolded. "I came prepared for a tough encounter, perhaps a few rounds to warm up, but I connected cleanly early on and just went for it. The fan support was incredible; it truly motivated me."

Manager Barry McGuigan, the esteemed former world champion, observed with immense satisfaction. "Tonight, Josh unequivocally demonstrated why we believe he's destined for greatness," McGuigan informed reporters. "His power, speed, and ring IQ are all exceptional. He flawlessly managed the pressure of fighting at Meadowbank in front of his home crowd. This was a definitive victory, sending a clear message to the super-lightweight division. We are not rushing anything; as I've stated before, we must select the correct fights at the optimal times to ensure his proper development. However, he is learning and advancing with each bout. We will analyze this performance and meticulously plan his next move. Significant challenges await Josh, and he is ready to face them. This performance merely confirms that he is indeed a very special talent, capable of reaching the pinnacle of the sport." This triumph marked another pivotal moment in Taylor's rapidly ascending professional journey, paving the way for even greater challenges and unequivocally establishing his quality on home soil against a respectable opponent, despite the brevity of the contest. The excitement surrounding Taylor intensified significantly after this commanding showing at Meadowbank, firmly cementing his status as one of Scotland's most thrilling boxing prospects, a future champion in the making, building upon his past Commonwealth Games achievements.

Romelu Lukaku, the 24-year-old Belgian striker, a £75 million signing from Everton, secured the winning goal seven minutes before the half-time whistle. This came after Henrikh Mkhitaryan had previously equalised, following United falling behind just 20 minutes into the match. The team then suffered further difficulties with Juan Mata's injury and Antonio Valencia's sending off.

Regarding Lukaku's decisive strike, Mourinho commented, "It's pleasing for him personally, but for me, it holds less significance." He reiterated, "I conveyed to him that the crucial aspect is the team's collective achievement, securing the three points, not his individual goal count. While his goal was indeed vital, it was scored in a game marked by considerable adversities, including conceding first, Mata's injury, and Valencia's red card. Such moments truly test a team's resilience, and I'm satisfied with our fighting spirit to clinch the victory, though we must learn from the mistakes that led to these challenging situations."

Mata's injury is a major concern. "He is an essential player for us, and his creative influence will be sorely missed. We will ascertain the full extent of the injury, but it appeared serious," Mourinho stated. Addressing Valencia's red card, he described it as an "unnecessary act of indiscipline which he acknowledges. An experienced player should avoid such an error, leaving his side with ten men and missing the subsequent fixture. We cannot afford these kinds of lapses if we aim to contend for significant honours."

"Romelu understands my high expectations, which extend beyond merely scoring goals to encompass his entire contribution," Mourinho continued. "I expect him to engage in link-up play, press defenders from the front, and be constantly involved in our attacking build-up, rather than simply waiting for scoring opportunities. Goals are a natural outcome of executing all other aspects correctly. He possesses the potential to develop into a complete forward for Manchester United, and we will persist in refining every facet of his game."

The team demonstrated remarkable character to secure the win despite numerous setbacks, including the initial deficit. "However, the overall performance wasn't flawless," Mourinho noted. "We allowed them excessive space at times and needed to be more clinical to settle the game sooner. We must show consistent improvement. We'll take the three points, meticulously analyse areas for betterment, and immediately shift our focus to the upcoming fixture. With a protracted season ahead, every player must sustain concentration, uphold discipline, and consistently produce top-tier performances devoid of detrimental mistakes."

An aircraft from the Rhodesian Squadron Royal Air Force, stationed at RAF Wittering, met with an accident at Holme on November 22, 1940. The pilot, Pilot Officer Harold Penketh of Brighton, perished in the crash, choosing not to eject. Following a geophysical survey of the location, remnants of his Spitfire were discovered. There are plans to exhibit these salvaged components to the public, serving as a powerful tribute to the sacrifices of World War Two.

At merely 20 years old, Pilot Officer Penketh was flying a Supermarine Spitfire Mk IIa, a vital fighter used extensively during and after the Battle of Britain. Although the precise reason for the crash is still undetermined, it is theorized he might have deliberately guided his crippled plane away from the village of Holme, a heroic act common among pilots then, to safeguard those on the ground. His choice to remain with the aircraft, even facing imminent peril, exemplifies the extraordinary bravery shown by numerous young servicemen during wartime. Harold Penketh's ultimate sacrifice is permanently commemorated on the Brighton & Hove War Memorial.

An archaeological team, collaborating with aviation historians and military specialists, conducted a thorough excavation after a successful geophysical survey. This advanced method had detected subsurface anomalies, indicating buried metal objects, which precisely guided them to the crash location. For several weeks, various artifacts were carefully brought to light, such as engine fragments, fuselage sections, cockpit instruments, and personal items thought to be Pilot Officer Penketh's. Every unearthed piece helps narrate the event, illustrating the ferocity of aerial warfare and the stark challenges confronted by those who protected the country's airspace.

Efforts are currently focused on conserving and stabilizing these valuable relics. There are proposals for an exhibition, possibly within a local museum or a specialized aviation heritage center. This display will feature the retrieved Spitfire parts and also recount Harold Penketh's personal narrative, alongside the broader context of the Rhodesian Squadron RAF's wartime operations from RAF Wittering. Intended as an educational resource, the exhibition will ensure that the courage of pilots like Penketh and the Spitfire's critical role in safeguarding Britain remain in public memory. It aims to offer visitors a direct connection to this historical event, fostering an understanding of freedom's immense human price and the enduring legacy of young airmen who operated from airfields such as RAF Wittering. The Brighton community, notably, has shown keen interest in commemorating one of their own through this important historical retrieval and remembrance. The overarching objective is to establish an appropriate and enduring tribute to Pilot Officer Harold Penketh and all service members.

Kathryn Trussler crafts sculptures from discarded consumer waste, including artificial turf and polystyrene. Her exhibition, opening at Elysium Gallery on May 19, was inspired by unique items found on Swansea beach. Ms. Trussler aims for her work to challenge the use of non-biodegradable materials for short-term purposes like packaging. She revealed the concept originated from what she initially perceived as a simple pile of pebbles. However, closer examination revealed they were old, weathered expanding foam pieces, stacked by decreasing size, reminiscent of the mass-produced 'Zen stones' art seen in medical offices or hotels.

Rehtaeh Parsons, a 17-year-old from Nova Scotia, took her own life in April after enduring relentless torment stemming from a photograph of her alleged rape by four boys, as reported by her mother. In connection with this image, two 18-year-old men were apprehended on Thursday. These individuals, whose identities remain undisclosed, are slated to face legal proceedings in a juvenile court.

Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP) Chief Superintendent Roland Wells, from the Halifax district, released a statement Thursday evening expressing hope that these arrests would aid in the community's healing process. He remarked, "A young girl has died in what was a tragic set of circumstances. We all need to reflect on how we as a community can come together in Rehtaeh's memory and see what we can do to work together to support our youth."

Regarding the charges, one of the men faces two counts related to the distribution of child pornography. The other individual has been charged with a single count each of creating child pornography and distributing child pornography. The RCMP clarified that the names of the accused would not be disclosed because they were legally considered youths at the time of the alleged offense. The police further cautioned Halifax residents against publicly revealing the accused's identities, warning of potential prosecution, and advised against any vigilante actions.

According to Rehtaeh's mother, Leah Parsons, her daughter attended a party in 2011 at the age of 15, where she became heavily intoxicated after consuming vodka. Rehtaeh confided in her parents that while severely inebriated, she was raped by four boys, and a photograph of the incident was taken. This image subsequently circulated online, leading to incessant bullying from her schoolmates. "She was never left alone," Ms Parsons informed CBC News in April following Rehtaeh's suicide. She elaborated that Rehtaeh's friends abandoned her, she faced constant harassment, and unknown boys began contacting her via text and Facebook, propositioning her for sex given her alleged history with their friends. "It just never stopped," her mother recounted.

Rehtaeh passed away in April in the hospital, several days after her suicide attempt. Initially, police stated there were insufficient grounds for arrests concerning either the alleged rape or the photograph. However, the investigation was reopened in April after new information came to light.

Rhys Webb is poised for his return to the Wales squad, having been named on the bench, marking his first game since a foot injury sustained in September. According to Davies, Webb's comeback was widely anticipated, with the team knowing he'd be back as soon as he was fit. Davies underscored the significant boost his presence provides, highlighting Webb's invaluable experience, leadership, and exceptional game management. He noted the immediate energy Webb brings to training, a testament to his intense dedication during recovery. His return is considered perfectly timed, especially with crucial matches, including a challenging Six Nations campaign, on the horizon, where his presence is expected to uplift the entire squad.

Despite the fierce competition for the scrum-half role in Wales, Webb's established pedigree distinguishes him. His rare talent for dictating the pace of play and exploiting defensive weaknesses sets him apart, and he is keen to make an immediate impact. The foot injury sustained in September proved more severe than initially assessed, necessitating extensive rehabilitation. Webb's resilience was evident throughout a rigorous recovery program. This period away from the field has only fueled his determination to perform for Wales. Despite media speculation about his return date, Webb remained focused, ensuring he only came back when completely fit.

Attention has now turned to the impending fixtures, with the much-anticipated clash against England featuring prominently. Webb's expertise is considered invaluable for such critical encounters, as his tactical understanding and composure under pressure will be crucial against England's formidable physicality. His reintegration into the squad also fosters healthy competition and provides mentorship for developing scrum-halves, thereby strengthening Wales's depth in the position. The coaching staff welcomes his experienced input. Beyond the pitch, Webb's professional standards and leadership qualities are exemplary, an influence vital for an ambitious team aiming to build momentum for future tournaments.

Davies further explained that every player understands the need to perform to secure a place, and Webb's return significantly elevates this standard, fostering improvement across the squad. He stressed the importance of cultivating a robust team, balancing seasoned experience with exciting young talent for sustained success. This healthy competition for places, he noted, extracts the best from each individual. Ultimately, everyone is dedicated to delivering strong performances for Wales, and Webb's presence unequivocally fortifies their position against any adversary, including England.

PwC's latest annual study reveals a significant drop in economic optimism, with only 37% of business leaders expecting improvement in 2015, a decrease from 44% the previous year. As might be expected, Russian executives, once the most confident, now exhibit the least optimism, grappling with challenges posed by international sanctions and plummeting oil prices. In the United Kingdom, concerns regarding the availability of skilled personnel have escalated dramatically. The scarcity of crucial talent, highlighted by the PwC findings, is perceived as a considerable impediment to the nation's growth and competitive edge. Many UK companies report difficulties recruiting and retaining staff with essential digital and technical capabilities, prompting greater investment in upskilling their current workforces and, where feasible, attracting international experts.

In contrast to the UK's talent deficit, business leaders in Germany and France expressed different primary worries. German CEOs, though somewhat more sanguine than their French counterparts, were largely preoccupied with a slowdown in global demand and geopolitical instability impacting their export-dependent sectors. The sluggish recovery within the eurozone also cast a shadow, with persistent concerns about deflation and consumer spending. French chief executives, meanwhile, were more focused on domestic regulatory burdens and the imperative for structural reforms to stimulate economic activity. Confidence levels remained subdued across both countries, reflecting a cautious European outlook amidst ongoing economic uncertainties and the lingering impact of the debt crisis.

On a global scale, PwC's survey of over 1,300 chief executives underscored a universal lean towards caution. Beyond Russia's particular difficulties arising from sanctions and falling oil prices, and the UK's distinct talent challenges, the prevailing sentiment pointed to a strategic consolidation. Only 37% of CEOs worldwide anticipated economic betterment, down from 44%. This marked decline signals a widespread sense of unpredictability across diverse regions, influenced by factors from commodity price volatility to geopolitical tensions. CEOs indicated an increased emphasis on operational efficiency, cost control, and strategies for organic expansion, with a reduced appetite for aggressive growth. Investment in innovation, particularly in digital technologies, emerged as a vital priority for building resilience and securing a competitive advantage in a volatile global marketplace.

On June 15, 2012, at the Campos Morumbi estate in Curuguaty, a violent clash during an operation to remove farmers from disputed land resulted in the deaths of six police officers and eleven protesters. This tragic event, widely termed the Curuguaty Massacre, involved landless farmers who asserted the estate was state property designated for agrarian reform. While four men were initially sentenced to lengthy prison terms ranging from 18 to 30 years, the subsequent legal proceedings faced intense scrutiny. Human rights organizations and international observers sharply criticized the trials of the eleven farmers, alleging deficiencies in due process and insufficient evidence connecting them to the police fatalities.

The massacre quickly escalated political tensions in Paraguay and served as the direct justification for the Paraguayan congress to swiftly impeach the then-President Fernando Lugo, a left-wing leader. His removal, mere days after the killings, was widely perceived as a politically motivated maneuver aimed at dismantling his land reform initiatives. Consequently, several regional bodies, including MERCOSUR and UNASUR, denounced Lugo's unseating as a 'parliamentary coup,' leading to Paraguay's temporary suspension from these blocs.

Despite convictions being issued in 2016, a pivotal development occurred in July 2017 when Paraguay's Supreme Court of Justice overturned the sentences against the eleven farmers, including the four previously mentioned. Citing a lack of concrete evidence and significant procedural errors, this landmark ruling led to their immediate liberation. The Curuguaty case thus embodies a complex legal narrative that highlights Paraguay's deep-rooted land disputes and political divisions, remaining a potent symbol in the country's ongoing quest for land rights and justice.

Dorian, 23, was forced to withdraw from the Dragons' New Year's Day loss to Ospreys during the first half. Dragons director of rugby Lyn Jones stated that Dorian has sustained a pectoral injury, which appears to be quite severe. Jones indicated this could sideline him for several months, a considerable blow given his excellent current form and his rising challenge for a spot in the national team, vying with Dan Biggar. Additionally, scrum-half Sarel Pretorius also departed the Liberty Stadium pitch due to a recurring calf problem.

However, the Dragons anticipate the return of Hallam Amos and Tyler Morgan later this month. These Wales internationals have been out of action since suffering shoulder injuries at the World Cup, but at least one is expected to be fit for the critical European Challenge Cup matches at home against Castres on January 15. Dragons boss Jones further commented that "they are impactful players who can bring a distinct quality." He added, "There's a strong possibility one of them will be back [to face Castres], though I'm uncertain which one." Jones praised the medical team, noting, "They've made excellent progress, and the medical department deserves credit for their rapid recovery efforts. They have recovered very well, and we anticipate both will participate in the European competition soon."

According to the Official Charts Company, this marks an unprecedented historical event: an artist simultaneously claiming the top two spots on the charts with entirely new tracks. The acclaimed singer expressed his profound delight, stating he was "incredibly chuffed" by the achievement. He added, "Both tracks mean a huge amount to me, so it really is amazing to see them go to the top of the chart together." This triumphant return follows Sheeran's year-long sabbatical, during which he deliberately disengaged from social media and touring to explore the world and "see more than the inside of a studio or a hotel room." This temporary withdrawal from public life evidently paid off, allowing him to rediscover his origins and draw new creative energy, which is clearly evident in his unparalleled chart domination. The Official Charts Company further validated this double chart-topping entry as a genuinely historic occasion, highlighting the massive public anticipation for fresh music from the globally admired singer-songwriter.

These two singles, 'Shape of You' and 'Castle on the Hill,' brilliantly illustrate the diverse range of Sheeran's musical talent. 'Shape of You' presents a memorable, rhythm-driven pop track featuring a delicate dance undertone, whereas 'Castle on the Hill' serves as an evocative, anthemic tribute to his youth spent in Framlingham, Suffolk, encapsulating the spirit of rural existence and early friendships. This juxtaposition of styles underscores his adaptability and wide appeal, securing both critical praise and widespread commercial triumph. The instant success of both compositions underscores the effectiveness of a meticulously planned return to the spotlight.

This extraordinary accomplishment unfolds within a fiercely contested musical environment. Although artists such as Drake have frequently topped the charts over the past few years with a succession of popular songs, Sheeran's simultaneous top-two placement represents an unparalleled achievement, emphasizing his unique artistry and devoted following. His comeback has unequivocally invigorated the UK charts, introducing a renewed surge of enthusiasm and establishing an entirely new standard for chart success.

Reacting to the news, Sheeran again expressed his deep appreciation to his fanbase, recognizing the immense effort and personal meaning invested in both compositions. "It's been a long time coming," he commented, alluding to the intensive creative work undertaken during his break. He further stated, "To have both songs resonate so deeply with people, especially 'Castle on the Hill' which is so personal, means the world to me." The Official Charts Company additionally noted the astonishing quantity of streams and downloads for the two tracks, which significantly outstripped all other contenders. This unmatched achievement firmly establishes Sheeran as a leading and highly esteemed musician of his era, illustrating how a period of absence can sometimes serve as an ideal impetus for even grander victories. His unique capacity to forge such a personal bond with his audience, combined with his undeniable skill in songwriting, continues to distinguish him in the worldwide music landscape. Enthusiastic fans eagerly anticipate more details about his upcoming album, which is now poised to be one of the year's most monumental releases. The initial enthusiastic response to these two singles indicates that his "gap year" has merely intensified his creative flow, resulting in an even more polished and resonant musical style. The global music community is observing intently as Sheeran persists in forging new paths and reshaping chart narratives, showcasing a timeless appeal that bridges different musical categories and age groups.

Chris Millar remains sidelined, while Keith Watson and Ally Gilchrist are still not cleared for a return. Ross County defender Paul Quinn will be rested for a week to recover from a knock sustained during the Rangers match. Positively, Michael Gardyne and Martin Woods are back in the squad after sitting out the draw with the Ibrox side, and Erik Cikos has recuperated from a dead leg.

St Johnstone's Ricky Foster expressed his satisfaction with their earlier season win at the venue and hopes for a similar result. He noted the strong desire to perform well against former teams, seeing it as an opportunity to prove oneself and emerge victorious. Foster added that these matches are enjoyable, provided they end in a win.

Ross County's Alex Schalk emphasized Saturday's game as a crucial chance to narrow the points gap with St Johnstone, urging his team to seize such opportunities. He confidently predicted an upcoming run of positive results that would propel them back into the top six, a goal the manager has for them as an established top-tier side. Despite their poor start, Schalk believes the squad's ability warrants them being alongside St Johnstone.

Previously unreleased archive footage brings together a vibrant tapestry of Ulster's past, showcasing events from Winston Churchill's notable Belfast visit in 1912 and a 1963 Viking re-enactment in a County Down coastal town, alongside stories of tourism, industrial legacy, and athletic endeavors. As part of a significant historical initiative called 'From Britain On Film', the British Film Institute (BFI) has made hundreds of previously unreleased films from its archives available for public online viewing at no cost. The collection chronicles royal tours and civic parades, including Churchill's 1912 speech at Belfast's Celtic Park, where he spoke to nationalists and endorsed Home Rule. Additionally, numerous travel films are featured, originally designed to promote Northern Ireland as a tourist destination to audiences in Great Britain and the United States, thereby boosting visitor numbers prior to the onset of the Troubles. The archive also highlights sporting events, such as the 1930 Ulster Tourist Trophy race, held at the Ards circuit in County Down, an event that drew thousands of onlookers and captivated the international motorsport community.

However, the most compelling material lies in the footage depicting everyday individuals engaged in remarkable activities. Scenes of workers in spinning mills and the construction of the M1 motorway at Stockman's Lane in Belfast showcase Northern Ireland's industrial peak. One film documents Northern Ireland's inaugural hosting of the World Ploughing Championships, where, appropriately, a local competitor claimed victory. This 1959 competition in Armoy, County Antrim, is preserved in colour footage, capturing Lawrence McMillan's triumphant moment as he secured the Golden Plough.

Yet, a 1938 recording from Belfast's Royal Victoria Hospital proves arguably the most insightful. It offers an uncommon look into its casualty department and operating theatres as they operated a decade before the National Health Service was established. While medical practices have progressed significantly over the subsequent eighty years, certain aspects of healthcare in Northern Ireland seem to persist; the film concludes with the hospital's management board chairman appealing for reduced waiting lists.

Francis Jones of Northern Ireland Screen, responsible for collecting much of this material, stated that the project's goal was to safeguard fragile films that were at risk of deterioration or loss. He added that film possesses a unique nostalgic value, distinct from engaging with textbooks or history books. "Witnessing the footage firsthand offers a visceral connection that truly resonates with viewers," he commented. The entire 'From Britain On Film' archive is accessible via the BFI Player.

North Ronaldsay Primary School's sole classroom will be held in reserve starting in August, following 12-year-old Teigan Scott's transition to secondary education in Kirkwall. This most northerly Orkney island is home to only around 50 residents. Orkney Islands Council stated the school would resume operation if additional families with young children relocate to the island. The facility also serves as a hub for local community groups. Island inhabitants attribute the scarcity of young families to inadequate transport connections. Teigan expressed to the BBC her excitement for secondary school but conveyed apprehension regarding her former school's future. "I'm eager to attend the larger school," she remarked. "However, a slight sadness lingers because the school's closure makes me fear the island could decline."

Councillor Kevin Woodbridge noted that North Ronaldsay's population has halved since his arrival in 1977. He commented, "It's deeply saddening, yet it illustrates the island's decline that has culminated in this situation." "When I first came, there were 17 pupils at the school and 127 residents on the island; now, the population stands at 50 to 60." He added, "The standard of living on the island could be significantly enhanced."

Billy Muir, who chairs the community council, described losing the school's sole pupil as "a severe setback for the community that will undoubtedly trigger wider consequences." He stated, "We require new housing to be constructed and new families to move in. A school needs several children, not just one." "Faster broadband is also essential." "There's no sense in sugar-coating things; we must be pragmatic. Hopefully, this situation draws attention to our predicament."

A spokesperson for the local authority explained: "The single classroom at North Ronaldsay Primary School is located within a building that accommodates various community amenities. The classroom will remain on standby from August and would be reactivated for educational use should families with primary-aged children relocate to the island. Meanwhile, it will stay accessible to all North Ronaldsay residents for various learning activities, overseen by the local community association. This strategy for keeping the room actively utilized was developed through discussions between Orkney Islands Council and several North Ronaldsay community groups."

My Local, a retailer with 125 outlets, is set to close 93 of its stores immediately. The remaining 32 locations will continue to operate while administrators search for potential buyers; otherwise, these too will eventually cease trading. The company had a workforce of 1,658 individuals. Acquired by Greybull Capital from supermarket giant Morrisons in September 2015, the chain, then known as Morrisons M Local, was divested as part of Morrisons' strategy to focus on larger superstores rather than smaller convenience formats. Despite Morrisons providing substantial financial backing, including a loan of up to £25 million to help stabilize and turn around the business, My Local struggled significantly after the acquisition. This investment proved inadequate to reverse its declining fortunes in a highly competitive market, facing strong opposition from established players like Tesco Express, Sainsbury's Local, and various discount retailers. Morrisons has committed to offering employment opportunities to former My Local staff.

The challenges My Local encountered under Greybull Capital's management were complex and varied. A difficult trading landscape emerged due to elevated operating expenses, fierce price competition, and evolving consumer shopping patterns. Despite attempts to rebrand the stores as ‘My Local’ and introduce a community-centric offering, the chain failed to achieve substantial market penetration or consistent profitability. The decision to appoint KPMG as administrators was a direct consequence of prolonged and severe financial strain, indicating that no sustainable future existed without drastic reorganization.

KPMG's immediate focus involves overseeing the closure of the 93 unprofitable stores and actively seeking purchasers for the remaining 32. Sources close to the administration suggest that securing a single buyer for this remaining portfolio might prove difficult, implying that these stores could be sold off individually or in smaller groups to other retailers or convenience store operators. The closure process will unfortunately lead to the loss of a considerable number of the 1,658 jobs. However, Morrisons' proactive offer to re-employ former My Local staff, wherever feasible, offers some comfort to those impacted, underscoring its continued involvement, having originally established and then divested the convenience division.

The collapse of My Local highlights the inherent difficulties within the convenience store sector, even for well-established operations. For Greybull Capital, this represents a notable setback, further diversifying their investment outcomes. The fate of the remaining 32 stores now entirely depends on KPMG's ability to secure buyers within a reasonable timeframe. Should this fail, these stores will also inevitably shut down, marking the complete disappearance of the My Local brand from high streets, less than a year after its high-profile re-launch under Greybull's ownership.

Lord Advocate Frank Mulholland informed Scottish Parliament members that a fatal accident inquiry would be convened regarding the death of Sheku Bayoh. Mr. Bayoh, 31, died on May 3 in police custody following an incident in Kirkcaldy. His family expressed welcome for the announcement, hoping the Lord Advocate would indeed establish the complete truth of what transpired.

Mr. Mulholland also conveyed to MSPs that additional work was still necessary from the Police Investigations and Review Commissioner (Pirc), particularly concerning the cause of death, before the overall inquiry could be finalized. He remarked on the profound impact of this tragedy on the family, having met them twice, noting their remarkable dignity in coping with their loss. He asserted they were justified in demanding answers, and that a thorough, impartial, and objective investigation was their due. Mulholland expressed confidence that this process could be conducted swiftly without compromising its comprehensiveness.

He further clarified that a fatal accident inquiry would proceed irrespective of any decisions regarding criminal proceedings, specifically because Mr. Bayoh had died while in detention. Mulholland explained that such an inquiry would permit all relevant evidence to be presented in a public court, open to both the public and media. This evidence would be rigorously scrutinized by all involved parties, including the family, enabling the Sheriff to make factual findings and recommendations concerning Mr. Bayoh's death in a judgment accessible to everyone.

Aamer Anwar, the solicitor representing Mr. Bayoh's family, commented that while the family always anticipated an FAI, they do not currently consider it a full resolution for Sheku Bayoh's death in custody. Anwar described an FAI as essentially the absolute minimum measure, adding that predicting the outcome of the investigations at this point would be premature, especially if they prove genuinely robust and impartial. He highlighted that nearly five months had passed since Sheku's death, and the family's hope was that the Lord Advocate could deliver the truth of what occurred, recognizing that true justice cannot be achieved without it.

A forthcoming cabinet discussion will address findings indicating that seventeen temporary contractors were compensated at over £500 daily, with two receiving more than £800 each day. The opposition Conservatives swiftly condemned Plymouth City Council's Labour administration. Councillor Ian Bowyer, who leads the Conservative group, characterized this spending on temporary personnel as a "scandalous waste of public funds." Bowyer voiced his profound disappointment, deeming it inexcusable that the Labour council permits millions to be diverted to outside consultants earning excessive daily fees, especially when crucial frontline services face reductions and residents experience financial difficulties. He asserted that this represents not merely inadequate financial oversight but a profound breach of public trust. The Conservatives, he noted, have consistently advocated for improved transparency and accountability concerning the council's reliance on agency staff. These extraordinarily high remuneration packages, he continued, expose a significant flaw in the council's employment strategy, suggesting an excessive dependence on expensive short-term fixes instead of fostering lasting internal expertise. Bowyer stressed that the public merits an explanation for the necessity and value provided by these highly paid temporary workers, particularly when permanent council employees face wage freezes. He concluded that this clearly highlights the Labour group's incompetence in managing city finances prudently, prioritizing costly, improvised solutions over strategic, sustainable planning for Plymouth's future.

During the Thameslink Programme, engineers unearthed the long-forgotten ticket hall and platforms of Southwark Park station. This station had a brief operational history, serving passengers solely between 1902 and 1915 before its permanent closure. The £6.5 billion Thameslink Programme involves an extensive upgrade of railway lines, stretching from New Cross Gate through London Bridge and Blackfriars, and extending north to St Pancras International. This ambitious project aims to revolutionize north-south rail travel throughout London and the South East. The substantial investment is designed to dramatically boost capacity and enhance connectivity, enabling more frequent and extended train services to operate directly through the heart of the city. The discovery of Southwark Park station underscores the rich historical layers often encountered by engineers undertaking major contemporary infrastructure developments. Key components of the Thameslink Programme include comprehensive remodelling of vital stations, such as London Bridge, alongside the construction of new railway infrastructure, all geared towards supporting these improved services. Ultimately, the programme will connect a broader network of destinations, from Brighton in the south to Peterborough and Cambridge in the north, facilitating seamless and dependable journeys across the capital. This crucial transport initiative seeks to meet increasing passenger demand, promising less congestion and a more efficient rail system for millions of daily commuters and travellers, thereby future-proofing the railway network.

A Thomson Holidays flight successfully delivered hundreds of passengers to the airport, touching down safely around 15:30 BST. The Boeing 737 aircraft promptly taxied to its gate, where ground staff awaited to assist with disembarkation. This smooth arrival was a testament to efficient airport operations, with all passengers, having experienced a comfortable journey, eager to commence their holidays.

Wales international Taylor sustained an injury during Wednesday's training session. Swansea manager Paul Clement is actively pursuing a deal to sign Norwich City's Sweden international, Martin Olsson. Clement emphasized his desire to strengthen the squad, particularly in defensive positions, and believes Olsson would be a valuable asset. The left-back has reportedly travelled to South Wales for a medical examination and discussions, with an agreement potentially finalized before the weekend. Clement, keen to make his mark since taking charge, considers securing Olsson a crucial step in his strategy to avoid Premier League relegation.

A six-year study followed over 200,000 Australians, both smokers and non-smokers aged 45 and older. BMC Medicine reported that the risk of death increased proportionally with cigarette consumption. Daily consumption of 10 cigarettes doubled this risk, and those smoking 20 cigarettes daily faced a four to five times greater likelihood of death. While a smoker might live a long life, their habit significantly reduces this probability. Smoking is known to elevate the risk of numerous health issues, such as heart disease and various cancers.

Cancer Research UK currently estimates that 50% of long-term smokers ultimately succumb to cancer or other diseases linked to smoking. However, more recent data indicates this proportion could be greater. Professor Emily Banks, the lead researcher of the Australian study, noted that newer investigations involving UK women, British physicians, and American Cancer Society volunteers have indicated the figure could be as high as 67%.

Banks commented that while the detrimental effects of smoking were known, their study provided direct, independent evidence corroborating concerning international trends. She added that despite Australia's low smoking rates, their research showed smokers faced approximately three times the risk of premature death compared to non-smokers, and were projected to die about 10 years sooner. George Butterworth, Cancer Research UK's tobacco policy manager, expressed significant worry that the adverse impact of smoking might be more severe than previously understood.

Butterworth noted that previous UK studies conservatively estimated that one in two long-term smokers die from smoking-related conditions, but the new Australian data suggested a higher risk. He cautioned that due to differences in smoking habits between Australia and the UK, such as consumption levels and starting age, the two-in-three figure might not directly translate to the UK population. Currently, around 13% of Australian adults smoke, whereas in the UK, this figure stands at approximately 20%.

Quitting smoking can substantially reduce an individual's health risks. NHS Smokefree states that a decade after cessation, the risk of lung cancer halves compared to continuing smokers, and the risk of heart attack becomes comparable to that of a non-smoker.

An extensive array of photographs, alongside medals and badges, is set to be auctioned in July. Auctioneer Charles Hanson described this discovery as a "time capsule" providing fresh insights into the war. The images were captured by Robert Oliver, a Royal Army Medical Corps sergeant who served with distinction and survived the harsh conditions of the Boer War. His carefully maintained collection offers an unrivaled view into soldiers' daily lives, the challenging landscapes, and the stark realities of early 20th-century conflict.

Among the items is his esteemed Queen's Medal for South Africa, featuring multiple clasps, which attests to his bravery and involvement in crucial campaigns, including those in the Orange Free State. This remarkable archive not only chronicles his personal journey but also furnishes vital historical context for the British Empire's operations during a period of significant global shifts. Charles Hanson highlighted the exceptional scarcity of such a comprehensive and personal archive, presenting historians and collectors with a unique chance to engage directly with the past.

Oliver’s photographs reveal both the resolute spirit of the troops and unexpected instances of camaraderie and quiet contemplation, contrasting sharply with the posed images often seen from that period. These unposed pictures, combined with his medals and personal effects, create a vivid depiction of a man who witnessed history unfold and possessed the prescience to record it. The archive's sheer breadth, detailing everything from medical stations to troop movements across the veld, establishes it as an invaluable resource for comprehending the human toll and strategic challenges faced by British forces. It truly represents, as Hanson observed, a time capsule, brimming with unshared narratives and forgotten perspectives that prompt a re-evaluation of existing conflict accounts. The auction is anticipated to attract international attention due to the rarity and historical significance of Oliver’s documentation of one of the British Empire's most arduous conflicts.

Between September and November, three incidents involving a single individual have been reported near the Hillhead Halls of Residence. The suspect is described as a white male, aged 17 to 20, approximately 5 ft 8 inches tall, with short dark hair and a slim build. He was consistently observed wearing a dark hooded top and dark trousers during all three occurrences.

The first incident occurred on the evening of Friday, September 15th, when a female student was approached and followed. A second event, on Tuesday, October 3rd, involved a similar approach followed by an attempted theft. The latest incident, on Wednesday, November 8th, escalated to an assault, although the victim did not sustain serious injuries. These events, all transpiring in the immediate vicinity of the Hillhead Halls, have understandably caused significant concern among both residents and staff.

Det. Constable Kirsty Munro, the investigating officer, confirmed that authorities are treating these matters with utmost seriousness and have increased patrols around the Hillhead Halls. She urged anyone with any information, no matter how minor, to come forward, emphasizing that identifying this individual is crucial to preventing further incidents. Residents are advised to remain vigilant and report any suspicious activity immediately to an officer, by calling 101, or anonymously through Crimestoppers.

The initial communication from the spacecraft following its Tuesday flyby suggests it navigated past the icy celestial body without incident, traveling at an astonishing speed of 14 kilometers per second (31,000 mph). This vital signal was received via a massive antenna in Madrid, Spain, part of NASA's global communications network. The transmission journeyed 4.7 billion kilometers across space, taking four hours and twenty-five minutes to reach Earth. Anticipation was high among scientists and engineers at the mission's control center in Laurel, Maryland, as they awaited crucial telemetry. Relief and elation swept through the room when the robust signal, brimming with invaluable data, was finally confirmed. A wave of applause, hugs, and congratulatory back-pats filled the control room, celebrating the culmination of years of tireless effort, meticulous planning, and numerous sleepless nights. This successful data transmission affirmed the spacecraft's integrity after its challenging close encounter, ensuring the safe delivery of the information it had gathered.

Early telemetry packets verified the optimal functioning of all onboard instruments, including its advanced high-resolution cameras, spectrometers, and magnetometers. Scientists promptly began processing the raw data, eager for their first insights into the enigmatic icy world. This successful flyby marks a significant milestone in our exploration of the outer solar system, expanding the limits of possibility and providing an unparalleled view of a celestial object previously only dimly perceived from a distance. The incoming data promises to fundamentally alter our understanding of cryogenic geological processes, the potential existence of subsurface oceans, and the conditions conducive to life beyond our planet.

Mission scientists anticipate dedicating months, perhaps even years, to meticulously analyze the downloaded information. Every fragment of data holds the potential to unveil new cosmic mysteries, ranging from the ice's composition to indicators of plumes or geological activity. The spacecraft's incredible odyssey, spanning billions of kilometers from Earth, has now delivered its initial, monumental reward, showcasing the ingenuity of its engineers and the unwavering dedication of its scientific team. This crucial 'transmission home' represents not only a technological triumph but also a profound testament to humanity's persistent curiosity and its innate drive to explore the universe. The forthcoming images and spectral readings will offer a rich trove of details about the world's surface features, any atmospheric presence, and its magnetic field interactions, thereby constructing a comprehensive portrait of this remote, mysterious entity. Having overcome the immediate challenges of the flyby and data delivery, the mission team now embarks on the equally thrilling endeavor of interpreting the spacecraft's observations and translating them into groundbreaking discoveries. This initial achievement lays the groundwork for in-depth analysis and potentially future missions to similar targets, fueled by the profound knowledge gained from this extraordinary encounter.

Prime Minister Mrs. May held discussions with Northern Ireland's First and Deputy First Ministers on Monday during a single-day visit to the region. She underscored the commitment to prevent a return to the "borders of the past." Her meeting with Taoiseach Kenny reportedly centered on Brexit's implications for British and Irish relations. Earlier in July, soon after becoming Prime Minister, Mrs. May had a phone conversation with Mr. Kenny, agreeing to strengthen the "strong relationship" between the UK and the Republic of Ireland.

Northern Ireland Secretary of State James Brokenshire characterized Mrs. May's Monday meeting with Arlene Foster and Martin McGuinness as productive. He also stated there was consensus on safeguarding existing border arrangements between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland. Brokenshire remarked that the Prime Minister had a very constructive discussion with the First and Deputy First Ministers, expressing a strong resolve to avoid the re-establishment of "borders of the past." He noted this theme also underpinned his earlier talks with the Taoiseach last Friday. Mr. Brokenshire further stated that existing "treaties and various other mechanisms" affirm a "distinct arrangement" between the United Kingdom and the Republic of Ireland.

Deputy First Minister Martin McGuinness expressed hope for a future arrangement that enables Northern Ireland residents to retain their European outlook as part of an innovative solution. DUP MP Gavin Robinson identified "two aspects" requiring consideration regarding the border situation. He explained that while talks have primarily addressed human mobility, future conversations must encompass trade, customs procedures, the potential for a single market, and any tariff differences, along with how such disparities would be managed. Robinson noted that while he foresaw no issues in establishing an arrangement based on the Common Travel Area, permitting free movement between the Republic of Ireland and the UK given their consistent immigration policies, he acknowledged that additional talks would likely be necessary.

An armed robbery at the Freshway General store in Southport on Tuesday evening around 9pm BST left a staff member with a facial injury and deeply shaken. Merseyside Police are appealing for witnesses following this incident. Detective Inspector Steve Reardon described it as a "shocking and violent attack" on a lone employee. He confirmed that multiple lines of enquiry are being pursued and urged anyone in the area who saw anything suspicious or has relevant dashcam footage to come forward immediately, stressing that even seemingly insignificant information could be crucial. Police patrols have been increased to reassure local residents.

A mother and her teenage daughter were reportedly pulled from their car by several men on a highway between Noida, a Delhi suburb, and Kanpur city on Friday, according to reports. Three male relatives traveling with them were assaulted and tied up. This incident has ignited nationwide outrage and raised critical questions about women's safety, particularly on national highways in Uttar Pradesh. The atrocious crime, which took place near Bulandshahr, has rekindled a fierce debate over law and order in the state. The Hindustan Times reported that the victims were forcibly removed from their vehicle, while male family members, including the patriarch, were restrained and attacked before the women were allegedly gang-raped by bandits.

The savage nature of this attack on a critical highway stretch linking the bustling Delhi suburb of Noida with Kanpur city has profoundly shaken the country. Political figures, women's rights advocates, and the general public have condemned the events, demanding swift justice for the victims and firm measures against those responsible. Protests have erupted in various cities, with demonstrators voicing their anger and fear, and calling for state government accountability. Critics point to an apparent failure in security, highlighting the vulnerability of travelers on these often-isolated routes. The Uttar Pradesh Police have initiated an extensive search, deploying numerous teams to apprehend the culprits, with senior officials vowing to spare no effort to ensure they face justice. This incident serves as a stark reminder of the ongoing difficulties in ensuring basic citizen safety, necessitating a re-evaluation of security protocols across the nation's road networks.

As of 18 January 2016, 19:54 GMT, VPN services significantly enhance online privacy and security. BBC Technology correspondent Chris Foxx explains their benefits for users in an era of increasing digital surveillance, particularly during this January period.

The observance features parades, speeches, and special gatherings, taking place on March 8th. This date was specifically chosen to spotlight significant accomplishments, particularly in sports. This year, Oxfordshire's celebrations will host Olympians Rebecca Adlington and Charlotte Dujardin, both OBE recipients. Sophie, a leading figure in community projects, is also anticipated. The event aims to foster local pride and recognize these individuals' inspiring influence on the national sporting landscape.

The International Bomber Command Centre, situated near Lincoln in Lincolnshire, features a prominent 102-foot spire. This striking structure symbolizes the wingspan of a Lancaster bomber and serves as a powerful emblem of the courage and sacrifice displayed by those who served. The centre stands as a poignant tribute, specifically honouring the 55,573 aircrew of Bomber Command who made the ultimate sacrifice during World War Two, many of whom perished over enemy territory. Beyond merely remembering the fallen, its mission is to educate future generations about Bomber Command's crucial role in the conflict and the profound human cost.

Recently, the memorial suffered an act of vandalism. Although the damage was minor, officials unequivocally described it as a profound act of disrespect. It is thought that the perpetrators used breeze blocks found on site to attempt to climb inside the memorial. This incident has deeply distressed veterans and all those committed to preserving Bomber Command's heritage, widely perceived as a direct insult to the fallen and their families.

Local police are actively investigating the matter and urging any witnesses to come forward. The community, alongside various veterans' organizations, has expressed widespread outrage, stressing the sacred nature of such memorials as vital reminders of historical sacrifice and the pursuit of peace. Work is currently underway to repair the superficial damage and bolster security at this significant site, which continues to attract visitors from across the globe keen to learn about the bravery of World War Two aircrew.

Last updated 16 November 2016, 14:02 GMT. On its streets, a new generation of photographers offers unique perspectives of the bustling megacity. Adeola Olagunju, 29, is a standout, having shared her approach to capturing Lagos with the BBC. Video Journalist: Roderick Macleod.

A boy and his father were assaulted in Castlemilk, Glasgow, on Friday evening around 8:05 PM. According to police reports, the young boy was walking along Ardencraig Quadrant, close to its intersection with Ardencraig Drive, when he was viciously attacked. His 52-year-old father, witnessing the assault, was also set upon when he intervened to protect his son. Both victims were subsequently hospitalized for treatment of facial injuries.

Police have initiated a full investigation into this distressing event and are seeking public assistance. Detective Inspector Peter McFarlane, who is leading the inquiry, characterized the attack as "senseless and brutal." He further explained that this was an unprovoked and violent assault targeting a young boy and his father, who was merely attempting to safeguard him. Both individuals have been profoundly shaken by this horrifying ordeal, and authorities are determined to apprehend those responsible. While the facial injuries sustained were not life-threatening, they necessitated medical attention and have caused considerable anguish.

DI McFarlane appealed to anyone present in the Ardencraig Quadrant or Ardencraig Drive areas of Castlemilk, Glasgow, around the time of the incident to come forward. He specifically requested information from anyone who might have observed suspicious individuals nearby or possesses dashcam or private CCTV footage that could aid the investigation. Emphasizing that even minor details could be crucial in understanding the events and identifying the attackers, he also acknowledged residents' concerns. He reassured the community that comprehensive inquiries are underway and that officers would be conducting visible patrols to offer reassurance.

Individuals with relevant information should contact Police Scotland by calling 101, referencing incident number [XXXX] from that day. An anonymous tip can also be provided to Crimestoppers at 0800 555 111. The police are dedicated to ensuring the perpetrators of this reprehensible act face justice.

Queried about potential legal amendments to marriage laws during an ongoing review, he told the BBC's Sunday Politics show he was neither aware of nor intended to implement any such changes. He mentioned the government was exploring humanist marriages in England and Wales. Humanism is a secular philosophy, and while humanist weddings are legally recognized in Scotland, they currently lack legal standing in England, Wales, and Northern Ireland. The Daily Mail reported on Tuesday that ministers had ordered a re-evaluation of wedding legislation, which might permit naturists to officiate weddings. It alleged that Mr. Grayling had issued a paper confirming that groups expressing interest in modifying wedding laws included British Naturism, an organisation promoting understanding and acceptance of outdoor nudism. However, Mr. Grayling clarified to the BBC: "It hasn't been ordered by me, I can tell you that." The justice secretary stressed the difference between someone merely "expressing an interest" and "something actually happening." He stated, "No nude marriage right now, as far as I'm concerned."

Campus streets will be pedestrianized, with additional trees, plants, public art, and cycle routes introduced. A University spokesperson noted the initiative aims to make the campus more inviting, secure, and environmentally friendly for all users.

Jointly funded by the Sheffield City Region Investment Fund and the University, the project is scheduled for completion by September, coinciding with the new academic year. Improvements will encompass public courtyards around the Arts Tower and Western Bank concourse, alongside the creation of a new public park near Broad Lane. Furthermore, additional pedestrian and cycle crossings will be established, and existing ones upgraded.

Keith Lilley, director of estates and facilities management, commented that the development would "transform the campus environment and support the University's links with the city centre." He expressed a desire for Sheffield residents to actively use the campus, whether for dining at its cafes, cycling through to Weston Park, or simply enjoying the newly created greener, safer spaces.

The University is providing £5.1 million for the work, complemented by £2.9 million from the Sheffield City Region Investment Fund. Leigh Bramall of Sheffield City Council highlighted that universities are "critical to the future of Sheffield and vital to the successful economic growth of the city." He further indicated that the improved campus would "emphasize the University's position as a key driver in the local economy."

A 30-year-old Larkhall resident, Paul Newall, tragically lost his life following a collision involving his Kawasaki motorcycle and a white Mazda 2 on the M74 northbound, specifically near junction 7, not far from Hamilton. The fatal incident took place around 1:30 PM on Saturday afternoon, triggering a large emergency services deployment. Despite the swift arrival of paramedics and police, Mr. Newall, known as a popular figure in the Larkhall community, was declared deceased at the site. The carriageway remained shut for several hours to facilitate a thorough accident investigation. Police Scotland is now appealing for witnesses or individuals with dashcam footage to contact them, as they investigate the circumstances of the deadly collision.

Zee Entertainment Enterprises has revealed its intention to dub its extensive collection of Bollywood films, originally recorded in Hindi, into Spanish. This endeavor forms the foundation of Zee Mundo, the company's pioneering effort to introduce Indian cinema to the Hispanic market. The strategic initiative aims to connect with the rapidly expanding Spanish-speaking demographic across the Americas, especially in vital regions like Mexico and the United States. Despite Bollywood's global appeal, language barriers have frequently hindered its widespread reach in areas where Hindi or English are not primary languages. By converting the Hindi dialogue into Spanish, Zee seeks to eliminate this obstacle, making the vibrant storytelling, intricate musical performances, and compelling plots more readily available to a new audience segment. Zee Mundo will feature a varied selection of genres, from action and romance to drama, all customized to local cultural preferences, thereby guaranteeing a diverse viewing experience for its Hispanic audience. This significant expansion highlights Zee Entertainment Enterprises' dedication to enhancing its global presence and securing a strong foothold in a previously untapped market.

The captain scored after Peter Jehle, Vaduz's goalkeeper, fumbled Kieran Smith's shot. Vaduz had established a 2-0 lead by halftime, following quick goals from Gonzalo Zarate and Maurice Brunner. Stuart Jones missed a golden opportunity for Bala to equalize late on, heading wide after Nathan Burke's free-kick found him unmarked at the back post. The decisive return leg will be held at Vaduz's Rheinpark Stadion on Thursday, July 6th. The winners will then face either Ballymena United or Norwegian side Odd in the second qualifying round.

Bala manager Colin Caton shared his thoughts with BBC Wales Sport: "I don't think we began the game particularly well; we were quite sluggish and overly cautious about knowing our opponents. Nevertheless, we still created good opportunities, including a clear penalty when Kieran [Smith] was pulled back after breaking through. Vaduz capitalized on their two first-half chances, which highlights the fine margins at this level. It's genuinely frustrating, as we had the better chances. If we can secure the first goal in the away leg, it's an away goal, and that will put them in a sticky situation. They seemed to be panicking towards the end here. It simply frustrates me that we performed so well, but at this level, you absolutely have to take your opportunities."

A 15-year-old girl, Dione Melville, passed away in East Calder, an event currently under police investigation. Emergency services responded to a house in the town on Sunday morning, but Dione was sadly pronounced deceased at the scene shortly after their arrival. This incident has resulted in a teenager being charged with supplying drugs.

Police Scotland confirmed that a 17-year-old male has been taken into custody and charged in connection with providing controlled substances; he is scheduled to appear at Livingston Sheriff Court. The inquiry into Dione's death is still active, with a post-mortem examination slated to establish the exact cause.

Dione, a popular student at St John's Academy in Livingston, is being widely commemorated by her friends and family. Social media has seen a flood of tributes, conveying shock and profound sadness. Her family issued a statement describing her as "our beautiful girl, who was loved by everyone." Lisa Grubb, a close family member, posted a heartfelt message online, warning young individuals about the dangers associated with drugs.

Chief Inspector Alistair Leitch, the Local Area Commander, expressed condolences to Dione's family, acknowledging the deep impact on the East Calder community. He confirmed that a thorough investigation is ongoing, with officers pursuing several lines of enquiry.

Police are urging anyone with pertinent information to contact Police Scotland by calling 101, quoting the specific incident number. The community continues to grapple with shock as further details come to light.

The Princess Royal Barracks at Deepcut in Surrey became the site of profound tragedy between 1995 and 2002, with four young soldiers dying from gunshot wounds. One of these was Private Sean Benton, a 20-year-old found dead with five gunshot wounds in June 1995 while on guard duty at a perimeter fence. The others who tragically lost their lives were Private Cheryl James, Private Geoff Gray, Private James Collinson, and Private Kevin Williams. Initially, all four deaths were officially classified as suicides, a determination fiercely and persistently challenged by their bereaved families for many years. These families tirelessly campaigned, steadfastly asserting that the circumstances surrounding their children's deaths were deeply suspicious and that the original investigations conducted were fundamentally flawed and inadequate. A significant breakthrough occurred in 2016 when a second inquest into Private Cheryl James’s death, also from Deepcut in 1995, dramatically overturned the initial finding, concluding instead that she was a victim of 'unlawful killing' rather than suicide. Inspired by this landmark ruling, Private Benton’s family, supported by human rights organization Liberty, has now secured consent from the Attorney General to formally apply to the High Court for a fresh inquest into his case.

These Deepcut fatalities soon escalated into a major national scandal, casting a harsh spotlight on the welfare provisions, widespread allegations of bullying, and the overall duty of care exercised within the British Army. The distressed families, frequently aided by human rights groups such as Liberty, relentlessly pursued the quashing of the original inquest verdicts and the initiation of new, impartial inquiries, convinced that vital evidence had either been overlooked or mishandled during the initial processes. Private Cheryl James’s case, in particular, gained renewed prominence when her parents, Des and Doreen James, succeeded in obtaining a fresh inquest after enduring years of arduous legal battles. This subsequent inquest heard compelling and disturbing evidence of a pervasive culture of fear, harassment, and even alleged sexual exploitation present at the barracks, which her family powerfully argued had directly contributed to her tragic demise.

In a parallel development, the family of Private Sean Benton, who was also discovered dead at the same Deepcut Barracks in Surrey, has for an extended period actively sought a new inquest into his death. His sister, Tracy Lewis, along with other family members, has consistently disputed the original suicide verdict, citing numerous inconsistencies and gaps in the available evidence, coupled with a worrying lack of proper investigation at the time of his death. The recent granting of consent by the Attorney General for Private Benton’s family to petition the High Court for a fresh inquest crucially underscores the profound and ongoing concerns about the integrity and thoroughness of the original inquiries conducted into these deeply tragic losses of life.

These pivotal and far-reaching cases, driven by the extraordinary persistence and unwavering courage of the bereaved families and their dedicated legal teams, have had a truly profound and lasting impact on the national understanding of military deaths and the standards of investigation within the armed forces. They have critically and emphatically highlighted the urgent need for independent oversight and a transparent, accountable justice process when service personnel die in non-combat circumstances. The ongoing re-examination of these deeply troubling incidents, particularly through High Court proceedings and the subsequent new inquests, represents a crucial and transformative moment in the collective quest for truth and accountability, offering a significant glimmer of hope for long-awaited closure to families who have endured decades of anguish, uncertainty, and unanswered questions regarding the deaths of their loved ones at Deepcut and similar military establishments.

In 2014, James Percival, aged 66, stated he performed mouth-to-mouth resuscitation on the newborn Jonathan Percival at the vicarage in Freckleton, Lancashire. However, Ruth Percival, 30, contested this, asserting she observed no attempts by him to revive the infant. The inquest was initially suspended in October when new medical findings prompted the coroner to refer the matter to legal authorities. By March, the Crown Prosecution Service concluded there was "insufficient evidence to pursue a prosecution against anyone in connection with Jonathan's death." This decision allowed Coroner Dr. James Adeley to reconvene the inquiry into the circumstances surrounding the child's passing. The hearing, which had begun the previous October, aims to establish the medical cause of death for Jonathan Percival, who was merely 36 hours old when he died at the Freckleton vicarage.

Earlier sessions revealed unsettling details, particularly the markedly different accounts provided by James and Ruth Percival. James Percival, who claimed to have delivered the baby, maintained he attempted to resuscitate the infant through mouth-to-mouth and chest compressions. He described the baby as being born "blue" and not breathing, which necessitated his immediate intervention. Conversely, Ruth Percival, the child's mother, presented a vastly different narrative. She testified that she was in the room throughout the crucial period and did not witness James Percival making any efforts to revive Jonathan, thereby casting significant doubt on his version of events.

The new medical evidence that prompted the coroner to involve prosecutors was not publicly disclosed, but it was understood to have raised specific questions concerning Jonathan's death and the care he received. Despite this, the CPS determined that the evidential threshold for criminal charges could not be met. Jonathan Percival's family, including Ruth Percival, continues to express a strong desire for a complete understanding of what happened to the newborn. The resumed inquest is expected to hear additional expert medical testimony and re-examine the conflicting statements from James and Ruth Percival. The coroner's ultimate goal is to provide a definitive conclusion on the cause and circumstances of Jonathan's tragic death in Freckleton, Lancashire. These ongoing legal proceedings continue to highlight the complexities and emotional toll of the case for all involved, particularly for the parents seeking answers.

The National Environment Research Council (NERC) faced scrutiny for its decision to conduct a public poll to name its new polar research vessel, a contest overwhelmingly won by "Boaty McBoatface." Professor Duncan Wingham, from the NERC, acknowledged the controversy had "put a smile" on people's faces. However, some Members of Parliament, disturbed by the public's mirth and potential ridicule, questioned whether ministers would hold him accountable for the situation. Despite the clear outcome of the poll, the NERC ultimately chose not to name its new £200 million vessel RRS Boaty McBoatface. Instead, it was designated RRS Sir David Attenborough, a choice intended to emphasize its serious scientific mission and critical role in understanding global environmental changes. This rejection of the public's preferred name sparked widespread anger and accusations that the NERC had disregarded democratic will, leading to significant social media uproar over perceived hypocrisy. Prof Wingham, facing intense scrutiny, defended the NERC's decision, arguing that a more dignified name was essential for a vessel undertaking vital polar and climate research. To appease public dissatisfaction, NERC announced a compromise: a remotely operated underwater vehicle (ROV) aboard the RRS Sir David Attenborough would be named 'Boaty McBoatface'. This ingenious solution allowed the beloved, quirky name to be integrated into the scientific mission, ensuring its unique legacy persisted. The entire saga became a memorable case study in public engagement, inextricably linking Professor Wingham and the National Environment Research Council with the Boaty McBoatface phenomenon.

Toulon's coach, Richard Cockerill, reportedly tried to negotiate Leigh Halfpenny's release for the Top 14 final on June 4, assuming his French club reached the showpiece event. Yet, Lions head coach Warren Gatland quickly rejected this proposition, asserting that the schedule was fixed. Gatland firmly stated that Halfpenny would be with the British & Irish Lions training camp for its entirety, stressing that the itinerary was clear and all players must be available from the very beginning. This unwavering position highlights Gatland's absolute dedication to player availability for the crucial tour preparations, deeming it non-negotiable for team unity and strategic development. The Lions squad, including prominent figures like Halfpenny, is set to gather for their pre-tour camp on May 22, just under two weeks prior to the potential Top 14 final. Gatland considers every moment of preparation invaluable, particularly with a rigorous ten-match itinerary, featuring three Tests against the reigning world champions, New Zealand.

Gatland has consistently underscored that the Lions tour's sanctity is paramount, demanding that all chosen players demonstrate full commitment and presence throughout the preparatory phase. This principle has been unequivocally established since the selection process began. The coaching staff is convinced that any early absences would seriously hinder the team's ability to coalesce and achieve the high-calibre performance necessary to contend with the All Blacks on their home ground. Halfpenny, celebrated for his formidable defence, precise goal-kicking, and potent counter-attacks, is deemed an indispensable part of Gatland's strategy. His history with past Lions tours, notably the triumphant 2013 series in Australia, makes his prompt integration into the current squad even more crucial. While Richard Cockerill's efforts to secure Leigh Halfpenny’s availability for such a key club match are understandable from Toulon's point of view, Gatland's steadfast rejection highlights the distinct significance and exacting requirements of the British & Irish Lions tour, which transcends typical club-versus-country rivalries. Attention is now firmly fixed on readying Leigh and his teammates for the immense challenge awaiting them in New Zealand.

Mohammed Abdurezek, with connections to Swansea and Newcastle, was discovered by a dog-walker in Siston, South Gloucestershire, suffering from several stab wounds. An autopsy concluded the 31-year-old's death resulted from multiple stab wounds. Three men, aged 42 and two 22, remain in police custody, an Avon and Somerset Police spokesperson confirmed.

Mencap and the Challenging Behaviour Foundation have consistently highlighted the dangers associated with placing patients far from their homes. This caution emerges as the findings of a critical review into the mistreatment of individuals at a private hospital near Bristol are scheduled for public release. The abuse at Winterbourne View was brought to light by secret filming conducted by the BBC Panorama program. In connection with these horrific events, eleven individuals have admitted charges of neglect and ill-treatment. The South Gloucestershire Safeguarding Adults Board (SAB) commissioned this comprehensive investigation, carried out by an independent expert. The review meticulously scrutinised the systemic failures that enabled such severe abuse at the facility. A primary concern, echoed by Mencap and the Challenging Behaviour Foundation, was the practice of placing patients a significant distance from their families and communities. These organisations have long campaigned against the inherent risks of such remote placements, which can isolate vulnerable people, impede family contact, and create environments where neglect and abuse are less likely to be detected.

The serious case review, initiated by the SAB, aimed to identify not only those directly responsible for the abuse but also broader institutional shortcomings and failures in commissioning care. It closely examined the inadequate, or often absent, oversight mechanisms from the local authorities and NHS trusts responsible for arranging placements at Winterbourne View. The anticipated findings are expected to be stark, revealing a catastrophic failure of a system designed to safeguard vulnerable adults.
