Conversely, Rigby's defence team asserted Ms. Smith's culpability, suggesting she had a history of losing her temper and acting violently. The court heard contradictory statements from both defendants, each attempting to shift the blame to the other. Social services had been involved with the family before AJ's death, with welfare concerns for the child raised repeatedly. Records of these interventions and assessments were presented as evidence. The trial, presided over by Mr. Justice Haddon-Cave at Stafford Crown Court, continues as medical experts, police officers, and other witnesses involved in the investigation provide testimony. The jury's responsibility is to determine who was accountable for Ayeeshia Jane Smith's tragic death, considering the intricate web of evidence and the opposing narratives presented by the defence and prosecution. The profoundly distressing nature of the case, involving a young child, has attracted significant public attention to the proceedings.

The four-bedroom Georgian house served as the backdrop where eight-year-old Kevin McCallister, portrayed by Macaulay Culkin, cleverly outsmarted two clumsy burglars. Earning over $477 million globally, equating to more than £291 million, the film firmly established itself as a holiday classic. This iconic Georgian residence, central to Kevin McCallister’s ingenious traps and escapades, was not purpose-built for the movie but was a genuine family home situated in Winnetka, Illinois. This distinctive property, immediately recognized by fans, functioned as the main filming location for many of Macaulay Culkin’s memorable scenes as the resourceful young protagonist. For decades, John and Cynthia Abendshien have owned the house, graciously allowing their private dwelling to be transformed into the McCallister family home throughout the production. They frequently share anecdotes about the filming process, particularly how the crew accommodated their family life, even utilizing parts of their home for staff facilities. The enduring charm of the film continues to draw curious visitors to the quiet suburban street, eager to glimpse the house where Kevin McCallister famously defended his territory against the Wet Bandits, forever intertwining its stately architecture with the timeless narrative of a boy's unforeseen holiday adventure.

At 88 years old, Hank Costain, a resident of Charminster near Dorchester, made his inaugural Spitfire flight in 1942, when he was just 19. The Supermarine Spitfire itself had its first flight from Eastleigh Aerodrome (now Southampton Airport) on March 5, 1936. Mr. Costain fondly recalled flying the Spitfire, calling the experience "absolutely marvellous." He elaborated, stating that the initial acceleration upon engaging the throttle felt like a powerful push, launching the aircraft forward instantly. The aircraft was incredibly responsive, he noted, describing its controls as lighter than other planes, allowing for rapid acceleration and effortless aerobatic maneuvers. However, he stressed the need for careful handling: "Treat a Spitfire well, and it would reciprocate; mishandle it or be negligent, and you'd face problems like ground looping." He also highlighted its delicate landing gear, prone to collapse.

Mr. Costain served in the Royal Air Force for 37 years. His combat flights in Spitfires spanned numerous regions, including Europe, North Africa, the Middle East, and Burma. During his service, he also trained others as a Spitfire instructor and later became a test pilot for the aircraft at 9MU Cosford, Shropshire. According to him, the Spitfire was highly coveted: "Every air force recruit dreamed of flying a Spitfire." He proudly claimed to have piloted "nearly all of the operational Spitfire variants," adding, "Few people remain who have experienced as many different Spitfire marks as I have."

Mr. Costain frequently fielded questions, both during and after his flying career, about whether he experienced fear during the war. He admitted, "I was terrified," but clarified his fear was primarily of "letting my friends see" his apprehension, leading him to resolve never to show it. Describing combat tactics, he noted that if attacked, a pilot would "turn sharply into the aggressor," preventing them from getting on their tail due to the Spitfire's superior maneuverability compared to German aircraft. Concluding, he emphasized, "We must never forget the Spitfire's pivotal role for England; it was virtually our nation's salvation."

A US military raid on a village in Yemen's Yakla district on Saturday resulted in the deaths of as many as 23 civilians, including 10 children, according to the rights group Reprieve. Yemeni sources also reported that the victims included the daughter of Anwar al-Awlaki, a militant killed by a US strike in 2011. This operation marked the first authorized military action by President Donald Trump. While the Pentagon asserted the mission successfully targeted al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP) and yielded valuable intelligence, these claims were quickly challenged. US officials had previously announced the death of Navy Seal William "Ryan" Owens, 36, and the wounding of three others during the raid. However, Yemeni officials and human rights organizations strongly disputed the US account, reporting a significantly higher civilian death toll and raising doubts about the mission's effectiveness and planning.

The UK-based human rights group Reprieve confirmed through its ground investigators the deaths of at least 23 non-combatants, among them ten children, during the Yakla operation. Eight-year-old Nawar al-Awlaki, whose father, the American-Yemeni cleric Anwar al-Awlaki, was killed by a US drone strike in 2011, was identified as one of the child victims, with her family verifying her death. This tragic loss ignited further public outcry and underscored the grim human cost inherent in counter-terrorism efforts in Yemen. Local accounts further detailed widespread destruction, with numerous homes damaged and civilians caught in the heavy crossfire.

The considerable civilian fatalities, coupled with the loss of a US serviceman, instantly brought the raid under severe scrutiny, especially given its status as the initial military endeavor sanctioned by President Trump's administration. Critics, including members of the US Congress, voiced apprehension regarding the intelligence that informed the mission's approval and its overall execution. Senator John McCain, then chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, initially characterized the mission as a "failure" due to the casualties, although he later moderated his position. Amid ongoing questions about the tactical achievements and broader strategic implications of the operation in Yakla, al-Bayda province, the US military launched an inquiry into the civilian deaths.

Burnley took an early lead through Jay Rodriguez, who headed in from close range after just three minutes, following a superb cross from Kieran Trippier. Despite later missing a penalty, awarded when Garath McCleary fouled Ben Mee, Rodriguez quickly netted his second goal, again heading in from another excellent Trippier delivery. For the visitors, Wolves, Adlene Guedioura went closest, rattling the crossbar with a powerful long-range shot early in the second half. However, in spite of their determined efforts, Wolves found it difficult to penetrate Burnley's staunch defence, expertly marshalled by Ben Mee. The home side, boosted by Rodriguez's brace, maintained significant possession in midfield, with Trippier consistently posing a threat down the right flank, his dangerous crosses causing constant problems.

Burnley's clear dominance persisted, and they pressed aggressively for a third goal to definitively seal the victory. Scott Arfield and George Boyd toiled effectively on the wings, creating space for their full-backs to push forward. Trippier, in particular, appeared to be delivering one of his most influential displays of the season, his pinpoint crosses repeatedly unsettling the Wolves penalty area. Nevertheless, Wolves' goalkeeper Carl Ikeme made several crucial interventions, including an outstanding save from a fierce Rodriguez volley that would have completed his hat-trick, preventing Burnley from extending their lead further.

As the match approached its conclusion, Wolves pushed higher up the pitch, desperate to find a goal that might rekindle their hopes. Garath McCleary, who had been involved in the earlier penalty incident, attempted to make amends with several incisive runs, but his efforts largely lacked support. Burnley’s defensive line, anchored by Ben Mee, remained resolute against the late pressure. Manager Sean Dyche responded with tactical substitutions, introducing fresh legs to bolster the midfield and defence, sustaining their high work rate. The game concluded with Burnley securing a comfortable 2-0 win, a scoreline that accurately reflected their superior attacking flair and defensive stability. Jay Rodriguez’s clinical finishing, combined with Kieran Trippier’s exceptional supply of balls, proved to be the decisive factors in a commanding performance by the Clarets. This victory propelled Burnley further up the Championship standings, solidifying their position as strong contenders for promotion. Wolves, meanwhile, were left to lament a squandered opportunity away from home.

West Ham is reportedly set to escalate their bid for striker Jermain Defoe, who started his career at the east London club. The 34-year-old has been a prolific scorer this season for Premier League strugglers Sunderland, netting 11 goals in 21 appearances. His most recent contributions came on Monday, where he scored two penalties as Sunderland twice recovered from a deficit to draw 2-2 with Liverpool at the Stadium of Light. These goals emphasized his enduring quality and critical importance to David Moyes’ relegation-battling squad.

Despite their precarious position in the Premier League, Sunderland remains unyielding in their stance that Defoe will not be sold. Manager Moyes has repeatedly highlighted that losing such a productive forward, who is indispensable to their offensive efforts, would severely compromise their hopes of avoiding relegation.

However, West Ham's interest remains steadfast. Manager Slaven Bilic is eager to acquire a seasoned goalscorer, as the Hammers have faced issues with inconsistent attacking output and injuries throughout the current season. Securing a player of Defoe's proven calibre and extensive Premier League experience is considered a crucial step to bolster their aspirations at the London Stadium. The improved offer from the east London club is understood to be approximately £6 million, yet Sunderland reportedly values him considerably higher, closer to £10-12 million, reflecting his irreplaceable status.

Defoe himself continues to concentrate solely on his on-field responsibilities, displaying unwavering commitment to the Black Cats. His primary objective is unequivocally helping Sunderland retain their top-flight status, a monumental challenge he has largely spearheaded. This transfer narrative is anticipated to unfold until the window closes, with West Ham expected to further test Sunderland's resolve, even as the Black Cats stand firm on their 'not for sale' position regarding their pivotal player.

In a crucial game in Italy, Treviso's scrum-half, Senioli, nearing the try-line, smiled and pointed towards Scarlets' Scott Williams. What seemed an assured score was dramatically thwarted by the Welsh international, celebrated for his tenacious defence and unyielding spirit, who launched himself in a desperate lunge. The passionate Italian crowd, roaring for Treviso, fell silent as Williams, against all expectations, managed to snag Senioli's ankle just inches from the try-line. This caused the Treviso player to stumble, losing his forward momentum and dislodging the ball he had been loosely cradling, expecting to score. The ball bounced tantalisingly close to the whitewash before a Scarlets forward, somewhat late but seizing the moment, pounced on it, securing possession. A collective groan from the Italian fans was instantly matched by a roar of relief from the few Welsh supporters present. Senioli, left sprawling on the turf, looked up in stunned disbelief, his initial smile replaced by a look of sheer frustration. Scott Williams, quickly upright, merely offered a silent nod, acknowledging the fierce rivalry of this cross-border match. This solitary act, highlighting Williams's tenacity, dramatically altered the game's momentum. Treviso, previously dominant, suddenly appeared unsettled, while Scarlets, energized by the miraculous defensive play, discovered a renewed burst of vigour. The game, vital for both clubs' European aspirations, now hung precariously, exemplifying the intense rugby rivalry between Italy and Wales.

After joining the Dons in August from Championship side Leeds, the 24-year-old was making his fourth appearance when he suffered an injury. Following an in-game collision, the former Manchester United player is scheduled to consult a surgeon next week. Dons manager Karl Robinson expressed the club's deep disappointment for Wootton, telling the club website that despite his brief tenure, Scott had made a "big impression" both on and off the pitch. Robinson added that Wootton's role as a popular leader makes this setback "a difficult one to take," but he's confident Scott will return "even bigger and better than before."

A report in the Journal of Aesthetic Nursing highlights an increasing number of individuals under 25 pursuing anti-wrinkle injections. This practice, clinicians warn, could lead to "frozen faces" that impede young people's natural ability to fully convey emotions. The British Association of Aesthetic Plastic Surgeons (BAAPS), a prominent UK organization, has declared cosmetic injections for teenagers to be "morally wrong." These treatments, including Botox, function by temporarily immobilizing muscles in the upper facial area, thereby diminishing the appearance of wrinkles that form during expressions like frowning.

Nurse practitioner Helen Collier, who conducted the study, identifies reality television and social media as key contributors to this concerning phenomenon. She notes that many young clients are swayed by the seemingly perfect, frequently filtered images prevalent online and in popular media, fostering unrealistic ideals regarding their own physical appearance. Collier, whose research is featured in the Journal of Aesthetic Nursing, voiced profound apprehension about the psychological ramifications of interfering with a developing brain's capacity for emotional expression and understanding. She clarified that the muscles treated with Botox are vital not just for frowning, but also for communicating a broad spectrum of human feelings, from astonishment to sorrow. The consistent paralysis of these muscles from a young age could obstruct a person's ability to genuinely feel and convey their emotions, potentially undermining their social maturation and emotional literacy.

The study revealed a shift where, unlike older patients who typically seek Botox to diminish existing signs of aging, younger people are increasingly choosing "preventative Botox" with the aim of pre-empting wrinkle formation. This change in rationale presents significant ethical challenges for clinicians. Ms. Collier contends that acquiring truly informed consent from teenagers is problematic, given their still-developing brains and potential inability to fully comprehend the lasting effects of such interventions. She stressed that cosmetic decisions, like those for Botox, demand a mature consideration of risks and benefits, a capacity many under-25s may not yet possess.

BAAPS has reiterated these worries, maintaining its firm opposition to cosmetic injections for individuals under 18, labeling the practice as "morally indefensible." For those between 18 and 25, BAAPS recommends extreme prudence and a comprehensive psychological evaluation prior to any treatment. The association champions mental health and positive body image, discouraging procedures that could permanently affect a young person's self-concept and emotional growth.

Collier's study, published in the Journal of Aesthetic Nursing, implores clinicians to place paramount importance on the mental health and developmental requirements of younger patients. She advocates for more stringent controls on the advertising and provision of cosmetic injectables to minors and young adults, proposing that mandatory reflection periods and psychological assessments become routine. She posits that practitioners bear a responsibility to safeguard susceptible individuals from potential detriment, which includes resisting commercial pressures to offer treatments that might not serve the patient's best interests. The research emphasizes an urgent societal imperative to move beyond the ceaseless quest for an artificial perfect image, instead fostering natural beauty and robust self-esteem among youth, both in the UK and worldwide. This necessitates informing both professionals and the public about the genuine scope and potential drawbacks of treatments like Botox, thereby guaranteeing well-considered decisions and ensuring the emotional and psychological welfare of young people remains the highest priority. The extensive long-term impact of Botox use within this demographic on collective emotional understanding and non-verbal interaction remains uncertain, further amplifying the apprehension of specialists such as Helen Collier.

Ciaran James Williamson tragically passed away after an incident at Craigton Cemetery in Cardonald, which occurred around 7:25 PM on Tuesday. He was officially pronounced dead at Yorkhill Hospital, where another ten-year-old boy was also admitted for treatment. Police have commenced an investigation to ascertain the full circumstances surrounding Ciaran James Williamson's death. The location of the incident, Craigton Cemetery, saw a significant police presence as officers cordoned off the scene for forensic examination. Authorities are appealing to the public for any information they might have concerning the tragic events of Tuesday evening. The community has expressed profound shock and sadness following the news of Ciaran's sudden death. Detectives are meticulously working to construct a complete timeline of the events that led to Ciaran James Williamson being pronounced deceased at Yorkhill Hospital, despite the tireless efforts of medical staff to save him. Further updates are expected as the inquiry continues.

Barry Manilow, the 72-year-old vocalist, was admitted to a Los Angeles hospital on Wednesday evening following a full-capacity concert. His management team confirmed via a Facebook post that the hospitalization was due to complications from surgery he underwent on Monday. Although the specifics of the procedure were not revealed, the team reassured fans that Manilow's condition was stable and he was recovering. This medical issue prompted the cancellation of his scheduled appearance at the Grammy Awards ceremony on Monday, where he was slated to perform a special tribute. The unexpected illness interrupted what had been a successful series of engagements for the popular singer, renowned globally for timeless tracks such as "Copacabana" and the classic ballad "Mandy." Fans quickly took to social media, sharing heartfelt messages and wishing the New York native a speedy recovery. His representatives stated that further updates concerning his health status and any potential effects on upcoming tour dates would be provided as soon as possible, emphasizing that his well-being is their highest priority. The music industry and his devoted fanbase are now hoping for the legendary entertainer's swift return to performing.

In a surprising turn of events, 38-year-old Open debutant, Manley, found himself briefly at the top of the leaderboard with a two-under-par score, achieved under arduous conditions at Royal Birkdale. Expressing his delight to BBC Radio Wales, Manley admitted, "I had aimed for par on my inaugural attempt." He concluded his round exceptionally, sinking an eagle on the par-five 17th and following it with a superb birdie on the par-four 18th, culminating in an impressive two-under-par round of 68. The Welshman, a relatively unknown figure on the professional golf circuit and making his first major championship appearance, appeared visibly thrilled, acknowledging the cheers of the appreciative crowd as he departed the final green. His remarkable performance, particularly his strong finish on the back-nine with three birdies and that crucial eagle, defied all pre-tournament predictions given the notoriously difficult weather.

Following his round, Manley spoke further with BBC Radio Wales, reflecting on his unexpected success. "Honestly, my sole hope was to make the cut," he confessed with a smile. "To find myself near the top of the standings, even temporarily, is beyond anything I could have envisioned. I've spent my entire life dreaming of playing in The Open, and to perform this way on the opening day, at a venue as legendary as Royal Birkdale, is truly surreal. The course was incredibly challenging today, with the wind and intermittent rain, so achieving such a score feels extraordinarily special."

His unexpected surge captured the immediate attention of both seasoned golf pundits and the broader media. The focus quickly shifted from established stars to this plucky newcomer who had, for a moment, stolen the spotlight. Manley's humble demeanor and evident joy resonated deeply with fans, who were captivated by his underdog narrative. While three more rounds remained, posing the challenge of sustaining such form, for one memorable day, the 38-year-old Welshman unequivocally announced his presence on golf's grandest stage, setting an ambitious new benchmark for himself and enriching the championship's story.

The body of 42-year-old Giuseppi Roncari was found by police officers on Blackburn Street in Salford at 7:20 PM BST on Monday. Greater Manchester Police detectives promptly initiated a murder investigation into his death. Mr. Roncari, believed to have lived locally, was confirmed dead at the scene. A Home Office post-mortem examination is scheduled to establish the precise cause of death. Police are appealing for anyone who noticed anything suspicious in the area around that time to come forward with information.

One of two daggers unearthed by British archaeologist Howard Carter in 1925 from the burial wrappings of the young King Tutankhamun featured a remarkably preserved iron blade. Its uncorroded state and the rarity of such metalwork in ancient Egypt, over 3,300 years after Tutankhamun's mummification, had long perplexed experts. However, a joint team of Italian and Egyptian researchers, employing a non-destructive X-ray technique, recently confirmed its extraterrestrial origin, almost certainly from a meteorite. Their study, detailed in *Meteoritics and Planetary Science*, revealed the blade’s elemental composition, which included high concentrations of nickel and cobalt—elements characteristic of iron meteorites but seldom found in terrestrial iron. This pivotal discovery conclusively resolved an enduring archaeological enigma that had puzzled scholars since Carter’s initial finding in Tutankhamun's tomb.

The advanced X-ray fluorescence analysis, conducted by experts from the Polytechnic University of Milan and the Egyptian Museum in Cairo, unequivocally established the blade's cosmic provenance. The presence of nickel, in particular, served as a crucial indicator, given its scarcity in high concentrations in iron extracted from Earth's ores. This suggests that ancient Egyptian metallurgists, despite their impressive skills in working with gold and copper, recognized and utilized this unique, naturally available material that descended from the sky. Furthermore, the dagger's exceptional resistance to corrosion over more than three millennia lends additional credence to its meteoric origin, as this type of iron is often more durable due to its distinct crystalline structure and composition.

This finding provides significant insights into the technological capabilities and material resources accessible during Egypt's New Kingdom period. It implies that the Egyptians were not only aware of falling "sky-iron" but also possessed the sophisticated knowledge to forge it into intricate, highly valued objects befitting a pharaoh like Tutankhamun. The cultural and symbolic significance of a material literally from the heavens would have been profound, undoubtedly enhancing the mystique and authority associated with the youthful monarch. Notably, the other dagger discovered alongside it was crafted from gold, sharply contrasting with the 'celestial' iron one and underscoring the iron blade's distinct and perhaps revered status. This research powerfully demonstrates the value of an interdisciplinary approach—integrating archaeology, art history, and modern scientific analysis—to unlock unprecedented understandings of Tutankhamun's past and his civilization.

For the first time, MPs have officially voted to endorse the commencement of the UK's exit from the European Union by the end of March. The government's chief whip displayed evident delight following tonight's vote. Ministers' strategic concession was paired with a clever provision, successfully persuading Labour to agree to their schedule for invoking Article 50 without needing substantial reciprocal commitments. This "clever provision" was the government's promise to publish a Brexit white paper and permit a parliamentary discussion on the negotiation strategy before Article 50's activation. This tactical offering provided crucial political protection for Labour MPs, particularly those representing pro-Remain areas. It enabled them to support the timetable, framing their backing as a push for parliamentary oversight rather than an acquiescence to Theresa May's plans. This allowed them to reassure worried constituents and evade charges of hindering the democratic process.

This parliamentary triumph holds immense significance for Theresa May. It strengthens her authority over the Brexit procedure, demonstrating her capacity to secure a House of Commons majority for her proposed timeline. The chief whip's satisfaction indicated the successful navigation of treacherous political waters, temporarily silencing her critics. This outcome bolsters May's position for intricate negotiations with the EU, reinforcing her assertion that the UK stands united in its determination to leave by the specified deadline. The focus now distinctly shifts from the mechanics of triggering Article 50 to articulating Britain's future relationship with Europe.

Nevertheless, profound divisions persist. While Labour's leadership found a pragmatic resolution, many within the party and the wider Remain camp remain apprehensive. The white paper grants only restricted genuine legislative influence over the final Brexit terms. Pro-remain voices will undoubtedly become more vocal as the immense complexities of extricating from the EU become clearer, especially concerning access to the single market and customs union. The forthcoming months will severely test the government’s determination and internal unity as Brexit’s true ramifications surface. This vote merely concludes the initial stage, paving the way for the far more challenging phase of withdrawal and negotiation.
